Title: Prove that $\sqrt 2 +\sqrt 3$ is irrational.
Content: Please prove that $\sqrt 2 + \sqrt 3$ is irrational. One of the proofs I've seen goes: If $\sqrt 2 +\sqrt 3$ is rational, then consider $(\sqrt 3 +\sqrt 2)(\sqrt 3 -\sqrt 2)=1$, which implies that $\sqrt 3 − \sqrt 2$ is rational. Hence, $\sqrt 3$ would be rational. It is impossible. So $\sqrt 2 +\sqrt 3$ is irrational. Now how do we know that if $\sqrt 3 -\sqrt 2$ is rational, then $\sqrt 3$ should be rational? Thank you.
AcceptedAnswer: if $a,b$ are rational, so is $a+b$ ... As $\sqrt{3}-\sqrt{2}$ and $\sqrt{3}+\sqrt{2}$ are rational, so is $\sqrt{3}-\sqrt{2}+\sqrt{3}+\sqrt{2}=2\sqrt{3}$ if $a,ab$ are rational, so is $b$ ... As $2,2\sqrt{3}$ are rational so is $\sqrt{3}$ ... here we have used two statements if $a,b$ are rational, so is $a+b$ ... if $a,ab$ are rational, so is $b$ ... convince your self that these results can be seen easily.. If not, for first ststement: As you can see if $a=\frac{p}{q},b=\frac{r}{s}$ then $a+b=\frac{ps+qr}{qs}$ and for second statement suppose $a=\frac{p}{q}$ and $ab=\frac{r}{s}$ then $b=\frac{qr}{ps}$ P.S : I like your idea $(\sqrt 3 +\sqrt 2)(\sqrt 3 -\sqrt 2)=1$ to prove irrationality... :)That is the reason I have tried to help you... all the best
